action_space.name: Assessment, Case Conceptualization, and Goal Setting
action_space.description: Gather comprehensive patient information, clarify presenting problems, symptoms, triggers, and history, collaboratively formulate an individualized case conceptualization, and establish measurable therapy goals.
action_space.goal: Develop accurate, individualized CBT case conceptualization and clear goals to guide effective, targeted interventions.

micro_actions.name: Conduct Clinical Interview and Structured Assessment
micro_actions.description: Ask targeted questions about symptoms, mood, functioning, history, strengths, comorbidities, safety/risk, and impairment using interviews and questionnaires.

micro_actions.name: Screen and Assess Severity and Safety
micro_actions.description: Inquire about suicidal ideation, substance use, risk factors, and conduct standardized severity ratings.

micro_actions.name: Clarify and Prioritize Problems and Goals
micro_actions.description: Collaborate to define specific presenting problems, set observable and achievable goals, and select treatment focus.

micro_actions.name: Formulate Problem List and Case Conceptualization
micro_actions.description: Summarize presenting issues, symptoms, triggers, safety behaviors, and contributing factors into a working cognitive model.

micro_actions.name: Clarify Diagnostic Features
micro_actions.description: Discuss symptoms and diagnoses through gentle inquiry and review, clarifying distinctions and functional impairment.

micro_actions.name: Rate and Track Symptoms, Mood, Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Use rating scales, symptom forms, or worksheets to monitor severity, frequency, conviction, and progress.

micro_actions.name: Map CBT/Five-Part Model
micro_actions.description: Identify and discuss links between environment, mood, thoughts, physical sensations, and behaviors.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Agenda and Goal Revision
micro_actions.description: Invite patient input on agenda, regularly review and update therapy goals as priorities change.

action_space.name: Therapeutic Alliance, Engagement, and Motivation Enhancement
action_space.description: Build a collaborative, empathic, safe therapeutic relationship, address doubts and motivational barriers, and foster active patient participation in CBT.
action_space.goal: Foster trust, collaboration, engagement, and motivation, maximizing patient openness and persistence.

micro_actions.name: Express Empathy and Warmth
micro_actions.description: Use affirming, supportive language, greet patient warmly, validate emotions, demonstrate cultural sensitivity.

micro_actions.name: Validate and Normalize Patient Experience
micro_actions.description: Acknowledge and validate emotional states, communicate that experiences are common within the CBT framework.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Stance and Shared Problem-Solving
micro_actions.description: Invite patient to be active participant, emphasize teamwork, and shared agenda-setting.

micro_actions.name: Elicit Patient Feedback
micro_actions.description: Ask for reactions, misunderstandings, comfort, or suggestions about session and therapy process.

micro_actions.name: Address Resistance, Ambivalence, and Doubts Nonjudgmentally
micro_actions.description: Discuss patient fears, reservations, or motivational barriers; negotiate compromises and troubleshoot obstacles.

micro_actions.name: Motivation Activation and Perseverance Support
micro_actions.description: Use motivational interviewing, flashcards, role models, normalize struggle, celebrate effort, and reinforce persistence.

micro_actions.name: Negotiate and Reinforce Autonomy and Choice
micro_actions.description: Emphasize patient's control over pace and choices; frame suggestions as experiments.

action_space.name: Psychoeducation and CBT Socialization
action_space.description: Provide education about CBT principles, model, rationale, session structure, and address misconceptions to increase understanding and buy-in.
action_space.goal: Enhance patient understanding and acceptance of CBT, normalize difficulties, promote informed, active participation.

micro_actions.name: Explain CBT/Cognitive Model
micro_actions.description: Describe key CBT concepts, connections between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors using concrete examples from patient’s life.

micro_actions.name: Introduce Session Structure
micro_actions.description: Outline typical CBT session flow: agenda, mood check, homework, feedback, rationale for structure.

micro_actions.name: Normalize Challenges and Misconceptions
micro_actions.description: Reassure patient about difficulty in learning CBT skills and correct myths about the therapy and psychological symptoms.

micro_actions.name: Educate about Emotional Disturbance
micro_actions.description: Distinguish healthy vs. unhealthy emotions and provide psychoeducation about emotion and mental health.

micro_actions.name: Introduce Therapy Materials and Tools
micro_actions.description: Present forms, homework, worksheets, diaries, and their rationale for use in CBT.

micro_actions.name: Collaboratively Decide Terminology
micro_actions.description: Invite patient input on language used (e.g., 'homework') to increase buy-in.

micro_actions.name: Address CBT Misconceptions and Stigma
micro_actions.description: Explore and correct inaccurate beliefs about CBT, set realistic expectations for recovery.

action_space.name: Mood, Thought, and Emotion Identification
action_space.description: Help patients observe, label, and rate moods, identify automatic and hot thoughts, and distinguish thoughts, emotions, and behaviors.
action_space.goal: Develop accurate self-awareness and identification of emotional and cognitive patterns.

micro_actions.name: Label and Rate Moods/Emotions
micro_actions.description: Guide patient in naming moods/emotions using descriptors and rating intensity on scales.

micro_actions.name: Distinguish Thoughts, Feelings, Behaviors
micro_actions.description: Help patient differentiate their thoughts, emotions, and behaviors using written forms, ABCs, or targeted questions.

micro_actions.name: Elicit Automatic Thoughts and Hot Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Prompt patient to report what was going through their mind in distressing situations; use imagery, role-play, or situation-specific prompts.

micro_actions.name: Clarify and Spell Out Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Assist patient to articulate brief or vague thoughts into clear cognitive statements.

micro_actions.name: Probe Sequential Automatic Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Continuously question to uncover additional or deeper automatic thoughts and meta-cognitions.

micro_actions.name: Normalize Thought-Emotion Confusion
micro_actions.description: Address confusion between thoughts and emotions, offer gentle correction.

micro_actions.name: Use Thought/Mood Records
micro_actions.description: Teach and support patient in completing thought, mood, or symptom records to document patterns.

action_space.name: Cognitive Distortion Identification and Evaluation
action_space.description: Teach patients to recognize and challenge cognitive distortions, errors, or biases in their automatic thoughts using Socratic questioning and guided discovery.
action_space.goal: Reduce cognitive distortions and promote more balanced, adaptive thinking.

micro_actions.name: Educate on Cognitive Distortions
micro_actions.description: Describe common distortions (catastrophizing, black-or-white thinking, mind reading) with examples.

micro_actions.name: Socratic Questioning/Guided Discovery
micro_actions.description: Use open-ended, gentle questions to explore evidence for and against automatic/hot thoughts, encouraging alternative perspectives.

micro_actions.name: Label and Challenge Biases/Errors
micro_actions.description: Coach patient to spot and label errors, then challenge them using disputation, cost-benefit analysis, or fact vs. interpretation training.

micro_actions.name: Imagery and Role-Play
micro_actions.description: Use guided imagery or role-play to access thoughts or errors difficult to identify.

micro_actions.name: Probe for Central or Most Distressing Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Identify and focus cognitive work on thoughts/images with greatest distress or impact.

micro_actions.name: Facts vs. Interpretations Training
micro_actions.description: Help patient differentiate factual evidence from interpretations or assumptions in their thinking.

action_space.name: Cognitive Restructuring and Development of Adaptive Alternatives
action_space.description: Challenge and modify unhelpful cognitions, facilitate the development and reinforcement of balanced, realistic thoughts and beliefs, and encourage emotional as well as rational acceptance.
action_space.goal: Adopt more adaptive, helpful beliefs and thought patterns to reduce distress and improve functioning.

micro_actions.name: Develop Alternative or Balanced Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Collaboratively generate and reinforce realistic, helpful alternatives, sometimes through perspective-taking or role-play.

micro_actions.name: Re-rate Mood and Thought Credibility
micro_actions.description: Guide patient to rate mood and conviction in alternative thoughts after cognitive restructuring.

micro_actions.name: Disputation and Cost–Benefit Analysis Techniques
micro_actions.description: Challenge negative beliefs using written forms, Socratic questioning, and pros/cons review.

micro_actions.name: Build Conviction in New Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Support evidence collection, repeated review, and behavioral testing of new beliefs.

micro_actions.name: Positive Data Logging
micro_actions.description: Encourage recording of positive evidence and feedback to reinforce adaptive beliefs and change.

micro_actions.name: Promote Emotional Acceptance and Generalization
micro_actions.description: Facilitate not only rational but affective acceptance of new beliefs and help apply learning across situations.

action_space.name: Identification and Modification of Core Beliefs, Schemas, and Rules
action_space.description: Identify, assess, and restructure intermediate/core beliefs, rules, and schemas underlying automatic thoughts through guided discovery, downward arrow, and belief modification techniques.
action_space.goal: Transform enduring dysfunctional beliefs and schemas into more adaptive, resilient cognitive frameworks.

micro_actions.name: Downward Arrow Technique
micro_actions.description: Systematically probe for deeper meanings underlying automatic thoughts to uncover intermediate/core beliefs and schemas.

micro_actions.name: Schema/Core Belief Inventory and Sentence Completion
micro_actions.description: Use structured questions and sentence completion to identify absolute beliefs and schemas.

micro_actions.name: Assess Belief Strength and Cognitive Continuum
micro_actions.description: Rate conviction in beliefs using scales and work on viewing beliefs as non-binary.

micro_actions.name: Convert Rules to Assumptions
micro_actions.description: Transform abstract rules into concrete 'if...then' assumptions for logical evaluation.

micro_actions.name: List Advantages/Disadvantages of Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Discuss pros and cons of maintaining current beliefs and schemas before modification.

micro_actions.name: Formulate and Practice Adaptive or New Beliefs
micro_actions.description: Collaboratively develop, record, and reinforce new adaptive beliefs via homework and daily practice.

micro_actions.name: Experiential and Role Play Techniques
micro_actions.description: Use role-play, emotional imagery, and advice-giving exercises to shift beliefs and test new schemas.

action_space.name: Behavioral Activation, Activity Scheduling, and Problem Solving
action_space.description: Encourage and plan engagement in constructive, pleasurable, mastery, and meaningful activities, and teach systematic problem-solving and coping strategies for avoidance, withdrawal, or dysphoria.
action_space.goal: Increase motivation, mood, self-efficacy, and adaptive coping through structured activity and problem-solving.

micro_actions.name: Present/Curate Activity List and Brainstorm Activity Ideas
micro_actions.description: Offer, generate, and collaboratively select enjoyable, mastery, or values-based activities.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Schedule Construction
micro_actions.description: Plan and structure activity schedules; adjust for ability, mood, and variety; review adherence.

micro_actions.name: Activity Monitoring and Rating
micro_actions.description: Track activity, pleasure, mastery, mood before and after tasks using schedules, logs, or self-report.

micro_actions.name: Graded Task Assignment (GTA)
micro_actions.description: Break larger/excessively challenging tasks into smaller, achievable steps.

micro_actions.name: Encourage Action Despite Mood
micro_actions.description: Promote principle that engaging in activity improves mood regardless of how the patient initially feels.

micro_actions.name: Credit List and Positive Data Assignment
micro_actions.description: Assign recording and reinforcement of positive actions and mastery events, highlight achievements.

micro_actions.name: Adjust Activity/Mood Balance
micro_actions.description: Balance rest, variety, and schedule demands to prevent overwhelm and enhance success.

micro_actions.name: Direct Problem-Solving Instruction
micro_actions.description: Teach stepwise problem-solving: specify problem, brainstorm solutions, select, implement, and evaluate.

micro_actions.name: Skills Deficit Assessment and Training
micro_actions.description: Assess for lacking skills and provide modeling, role-play, teaching, or external referral as needed.

action_space.name: Behavioral Experiments, Graded Exposure, and Coping Practice
action_space.description: Plan, assign, and conduct behavioral experiments and graded exposure tasks to test beliefs, challenge safety behaviors, and build adaptive coping skills.
action_space.goal: Disconfirm dysfunctional beliefs, reduce avoidance and anxiety, and promote experiential learning and adaptive coping.

micro_actions.name: Design and Plan Behavioral Experiments
micro_actions.description: Collaboratively define experiments to test specific beliefs, predictions, and hypotheses; state planned steps.

micro_actions.name: Construct Exposure Hierarchy/Fear Ladder
micro_actions.description: List, rate, and sequence feared or avoided situations for systematic graded exposure.

micro_actions.name: Initiate Graded Exposure/Practice
micro_actions.description: Introduce least-difficult step first and coach/support patient in exposure tasks, in vivo or imaginal.

micro_actions.name: Address, Drop, or Reduce Safety Behaviors
micro_actions.description: Identify safety behaviors (avoiding, checking, distraction), plan for their reduction or elimination, and observe impact.

micro_actions.name: Teach and Apply Coping Skills
micro_actions.description: Model, rehearse, and reinforce coping strategies (breathing, relaxation, mindfulness) during experiments and exposures.

micro_actions.name: Monitor and Review Outcomes
micro_actions.description: Track and discuss experiment/exposure outcomes, reinforce progress, and update beliefs or strategies as needed.

micro_actions.name: Modify Difficulty and Troubleshoot Barriers
micro_actions.description: Adjust challenge level of experiments/exposures; collaboratively problem-solve and adapt as necessary.

micro_actions.name: Assign Between-Session Exposure/Homework
micro_actions.description: Set between-session exposure or coping skills tasks and review progress at next session.

action_space.name: Emotional Identification, Processing, and Regulation
action_space.description: Facilitate identification, labeling, and regulation of emotions; teach strategies for healthy emotional processing and tolerance.
action_space.goal: Increase emotional fluency, insight, regulation, and tolerance; reduce avoidance and distress.

micro_actions.name: Teach Emotion Vocabulary
micro_actions.description: Introduce emotion word lists, charts, or guided exercises to help patient label and identify emotions.

micro_actions.name: Label and Distinguish Emotional States
micro_actions.description: Facilitate accurate identification of emotions and separation of healthy/unhealthy variants.

micro_actions.name: Intensity Rating Techniques
micro_actions.description: Guide patient to rate emotional intensity on numerical or qualitative scales for monitoring.

micro_actions.name: Promote Non-Judgmental Observation and Mindfulness
micro_actions.description: Coach patient in observing/tolerating emotions, thoughts, or sensations without suppression or judgment.

micro_actions.name: Normalize and Validate Emotional Reactions/Struggle
micro_actions.description: Emphasize normality of emotional suffering, encourage healthy toleration and self-compassion.

action_space.name: Social Skills, Assertiveness, and Communication Training
action_space.description: Teach, model, and rehearse skills for social interaction, assertiveness, communication, and interpersonal effectiveness.
action_space.goal: Enhance coping abilities, social competence, and emotional well-being in relationships and daily life.

micro_actions.name: Social Skills Instruction and Role-Play
micro_actions.description: Teach, model, and rehearse initiating, maintaining, and ending conversations, practicing assertiveness and boundaries with feedback.

micro_actions.name: Assertiveness Training
micro_actions.description: Educate about assertive behaviors, model them, role-play difficult situations, and assign real-life practice.

micro_actions.name: Communication Skills Training
micro_actions.description: Coach patient in using 'I' statements, specific requests, positive reinforcement, and constructive feedback.

micro_actions.name: Active Listening and Validation
micro_actions.description: Demonstrate attentive listening, reflecting, validating, and showing empathy toward others.

action_space.name: Values Clarification, Acceptance, and Mindfulness Interventions
action_space.description: Facilitate acceptance of ongoing or unchangeable distress, guide clarification of personal values, and teach mindfulness-based strategies.
action_space.goal: Promote meaningful engagement, tolerance of distress, and mindful living aligned with personal values.

micro_actions.name: Guide Values Exploration and Clarification
micro_actions.description: Facilitate reflections on sources of meaning, values, and priorities, and help patient articulate and list them.

micro_actions.name: Encourage Value-Based Activity Planning
micro_actions.description: Support patient in structuring regular actions and habits that reflect identified values.

micro_actions.name: Introduce Acceptance Frameworks
micro_actions.description: Teach nonjudgmental observation and acceptance of thoughts and emotions.

micro_actions.name: Practice Mindfulness Exercises
micro_actions.description: Facilitate formal and informal mindfulness strategies in and out of sessions.

micro_actions.name: Normalize Value Disconnection and Prioritization
micro_actions.description: Discuss impact of life events on changing values or priorities, and support re-alignment.

action_space.name: Targeted Symptom Management and Adaptation
action_space.description: Apply tailored CBT tools and protocols for specific disorders or challenges (e.g., sleep, anger, OCD, health anxiety), adapt interventions for complex or severe presentations.
action_space.goal: Facilitate symptom relief and functional improvement using targeted, individualized approaches.

micro_actions.name: Use Disorder-Specific Psychoeducation
micro_actions.description: Provide information and education tailored to patient's diagnosis (e.g., sleep hygiene, panic mechanisms).

micro_actions.name: Teach Active Symptom Management
micro_actions.description: Guide patients through disorder-specific exercises (e.g., ERP for OCD, urge management for addiction).

micro_actions.name: Monitor and Record Symptoms
micro_actions.description: Assign regular documentation of symptom frequency, intensity, and patterns using diaries or logs.

micro_actions.name: Facilitate Acceptance and Distress Tolerance
micro_actions.description: Promote skills for tolerating symptoms and cravings, reducing avoidance and reactivity.

micro_actions.name: Integrate Therapy with Medication Management
micro_actions.description: Support medication adherence, educate about side effects, and collaborate with prescribers as needed.

micro_actions.name: Refer to Additional Professional Support
micro_actions.description: Recognize CBT/self-help limits and refer for assessment, medication, or specialist treatment as appropriate.

action_space.name: Homework Assignment, Review, and Adherence
action_space.description: Collaboratively plan, assign, and review between-session tasks to reinforce skill acquisition, address barriers, and generalize learning outside sessions.
action_space.goal: Promote skill acquisition, generalization, and adherence; identify and address obstacles to assignment completion.

micro_actions.name: Collaborative Assignment Planning and Initiation
micro_actions.description: Devise, tailor, and initiate homework tasks together, preview in-session as needed to increase adherence.

micro_actions.name: Provide Rationale and Recording
micro_actions.description: Explain rationale, ensure understanding, and have patient record rationale and assignment details.

micro_actions.name: Anticipate and Address Obstacles
micro_actions.description: Assess likelihood of completion, collaboratively problem-solve barriers, and adapt assignments.

micro_actions.name: Problem-Solve Homework Nonadherence
micro_actions.description: Explore reasons for noncompletion and modify assignment for achievability.

micro_actions.name: Homework Review and Reinforcement
micro_actions.description: Review completed assignments, reinforce skills learned, and adjust tasks as needed.

micro_actions.name: Use Therapy Notebook and Skill Trackers
micro_actions.description: Encourage use of notes, worksheets, and skill trackers for ongoing self-management.

action_space.name: Relapse Prevention, Maintenance, and Termination
action_space.description: Prepare patient for therapy conclusion by reviewing skills, planning for setbacks, normalizing relapse, and developing strategies for ongoing self-management.
action_space.goal: Sustain therapeutic gains, empower patient for lifelong adaptive self-management, and minimize relapse risk.

micro_actions.name: Normalize Setbacks and Relapse
micro_actions.description: Discuss possibility and acceptance of setbacks as part of recovery; rehearse adaptive responses.

micro_actions.name: Review and Consolidate Skills
micro_actions.description: Organize, review, and reinforce skills and strategies learned for future use.

micro_actions.name: Coping Card Creation and Relapse Action Plans
micro_actions.description: Help patient write coping strategies, reminders, and detailed action plans for future crises or setbacks.

micro_actions.name: Support Network Planning
micro_actions.description: Identify alternative supports and encourage planning for social connection during post-therapy challenges.

micro_actions.name: Booster Session Scheduling and Self-Help
micro_actions.description: Arrange periodic booster sessions or self-help strategies, plan homework or continued skill practice.

micro_actions.name: Identify Relapse Triggers and Warning Signs
micro_actions.description: Specify high-risk situations, monitor warning signs, and rehearse responses.

micro_actions.name: Address Responsibility, Self-Compassion, and Emotional Closure
micro_actions.description: Help patient balance responsibility and self-compassion, and support therapy termination process.

action_space.name: Therapist Self-Monitoring and Skill Development
action_space.description: Therapist monitors their own cognitions, skills, and reactions to enhance CBT delivery and repair alliance ruptures as needed.
action_space.goal: Maintain therapist effectiveness, self-awareness, and ongoing therapeutic skill refinement.

micro_actions.name: Self-Evaluate Automatic Thoughts
micro_actions.description: Therapist monitors personal cognitions and emotions affecting therapy and adapts responses using CBT tools.

micro_actions.name: Review Session Recordings/Supervision
micro_actions.description: Therapist records and reviews sessions, consults supervisor/colleague for feedback and skill improvement.

micro_actions.name: Use CBT Tools Personally
micro_actions.description: Therapist practices CBT techniques on self to increase mastery and empathy for patient learning difficulties.

micro_actions.name: Seek Ongoing Training
micro_actions.description: Therapist attends supervision, reads literature, and engages in training activities for expertise development.

micro_actions.name: Monitor and Address Alliance Ruptures
micro_actions.description: Therapist reflects on alliance, models apology, and collaborates with patient to repair relationship and adjust therapeutic approach.

Conversation_states.Description: Strength of trust, collaboration, and rapport between therapist and patient; guides engagement, openness, and readiness to address challenging content.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: poor/ruptured relationship, mistrust; 1.0: strong supportive alliance, full collaboration; intermediate: varying degrees of engagement and trust.

Conversation_states.Description: Extent to which session follows planned CBT structure (agenda, mood check, homework review, defined goals); influences pace, focus, and quality of work.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: no structure/disorganized/off agenda; 1.0: fully structured/focused CBT session; intermediate: partial adherence.

Conversation_states.Description: Patient's willingness, openness, and participation in CBT, including effort with tasks and exercises; informs intervention choice and depth.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: disengaged, resistant, unwilling; 1.0: highly engaged, motivated, proactive; intermediate: partial participation.

Conversation_states.Description: Clarity, specificity, and relevance of patient’s problem definition and session prioritization; supports focused interventions.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: rambling, vague, off-topic; 1.0: clear, specific, prioritized; intermediate: somewhat defined.

Conversation_states.Description: Clarity and measurability of therapy goals and degree of progress toward them; guides ongoing intervention selection and tracks motivation.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: undefined, vague, no progress; 1.0: specific/actionable, goal achieved; intermediate: partial specificity or progress.

Conversation_states.Description: Patient’s understanding and use of CBT theoretical principles and techniques (thought records, experiments); influences psychoeducation and intervention depth.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: confused/uninformed/no skill use; 1.0: fully understands, proficient, applies skills; intermediate: partial understanding/use.

Conversation_states.Description: Degree to which automatic thoughts are identified, discussed, and explored for validity and emotional charge ('hotness'); central for cognitive restructuring.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: no identification/unaware; 1.0: central thoughts actively explored and emotionally charged; intermediate: occasional identification.

Conversation_states.Description: Patient’s ability to identify and label cognitive distortions (e.g., catastrophizing, all-or-nothing, overgeneralization); guides cognitive restructuring.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: unable/unaware; 1.0: consistently recognizes distortions; intermediate: occasional recognition.

Conversation_states.Description: Insight and identification of deep-seated, maladaptive core beliefs or schemas; strength of conviction impacts mood and guides therapy depth.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: dormant/unaware/no endorsement; 1.0: highly salient, fully endorsed; intermediate: partially activated/weakly endorsed.

Conversation_states.Description: Degree of inflexibility or openness in patient beliefs, including emotional and cognitive endorsement of alternative/adaptive beliefs.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: flexible, open, accepts healthy/adaptive beliefs; 1.0: highly rigid, unable to change beliefs; intermediate: partial flexibility.

Conversation_states.Description: Patient’s ability to emotionally and cognitively accept, value, and apply adaptive or alternative thoughts/responses.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: not accepted; 1.0: fully accepted and internalized; intermediate: partial or intellectual acceptance.

Conversation_states.Description: Extent to which patient objectively evaluates automatic thoughts using evidence for and against, including credibility of restructured perspectives.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: not at all; 1.0: consistently/reliably evaluates and modifies thoughts with evidence; intermediate: occasional or superficial evaluation.

Conversation_states.Description: Patient’s acquisition, practice, and generalization of CBT coping/problem-solving skills (thought challenging, behavioral activation, relaxation, etc.) into daily life.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: no skill use/acquisition/basic understanding only; 1.0: independent, fluent, automatic use across contexts; intermediate: partial mastery, inconsistent use.

Conversation_states.Description: Consistency and quality of completing between-session CBT homework, experiments, or logs; impacts progress and future planning.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: never completed/non-adherent; 1.0: always completed, high quality/comprehensive; intermediate: occasional or partial adherence.

Conversation_states.Description: Degree of design, execution, and learning from behavioral experiments and coping practices (including willingness and challenge appropriateness).
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: avoidant/refuses; 1.0: active/willing/ongoing/appropriate challenge; intermediate: inconsistent engagement.

Conversation_states.Description: Frequency and quality of engaging in pleasurable, mastery, and value-based activities; relevant for mood improvement and symptom reduction.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: inactive/withdrawn; 1.0: fully active, frequent engagement; intermediate: partial or inconsistent activity.

Conversation_states.Description: Degree and generalization of behavioral/cognitive avoidance, use of safety/reassurance behaviors or rituals; guides exposure planning and intervention.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: no avoidance or safety behavior; 1.0: pervasive avoidance, constant reliance on safety measures; intermediate: situational/use fading.

Conversation_states.Description: Current intensity of negative emotions (sadness, anxiety, anger, shame, guilt) affecting patient functioning; guides pacing and intervention choice.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: none/calm/neutral; 1.0: extreme distress/crisis; intermediate: mild to moderate symptoms.

Conversation_states.Description: Overall mood rating, including intensity, frequency, and duration of mood episodes (depression, anxiety, elevated mood); used for risk assessment and tracking.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: neutral/normal mood, low intensity; 1.0: extreme/abnormal, constant, or persistent mood; intermediate: variable.

Conversation_states.Description: Frequency and intensity of repetitive negative thinking, worry, or intrusive thoughts; affects mood and increases impairment.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: absent; 1.0: persistent, constant, impairing; intermediate: occasional or moderate.

Conversation_states.Description: Patient’s awareness and understanding of their thoughts, symptoms, beliefs, behaviors, and patterns; predicts engagement and intervention targets.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: none/unaware/denial; 1.0: high/full/accurate insight; intermediate: partial self-understanding.

Conversation_states.Description: Patient’s ability and frequency of observing, accepting, and co-existing with distressing moods/thoughts without judgment or avoidance; supports emotional tolerance and change.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: unable/unpracticed; 1.0: consistently practiced, skilled acceptance; intermediate: occasional use.

Conversation_states.Description: Degree of patient’s discomfort, avoidance, or acceptance with ambiguity and uncertain situations; relevant for anxiety, GAD, OCD, perfectionism.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: cannot tolerate uncertainty/seeks reassurance; 1.0: fully tolerant of uncertainty; intermediate: partial acceptance, situational tolerance.

Conversation_states.Description: Patient’s motivation and persistence to work toward goals, try new strategies, and engage in therapy; determines progress and intervention type.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: no motivation, resistant, ambivalent; 1.0: very strong motivation, persistent, hopefulness; intermediate: variable readiness/ambivalence.

Conversation_states.Description: Patient’s ability to accurately identify and label distinct emotions; impacts emotional processing and tool use.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: confused, unable to label emotions; 1.0: clear, precise, consistent labeling; intermediate: partial ability.

Conversation_states.Description: Degree of unconditional self-acceptance, absence of global negative self-labels, and positive self-worth; affects engagement and risk of negative cycles.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: low self-acceptance/esteem/self-condemning; 1.0: high, unconditional self-acceptance; intermediate: variable.

Conversation_states.Description: Current safety concerns, including suicidal ideation, self-harm, mania, or medical complications; determines priority interventions and session structure.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: no acute risk/safe; 1.0: high/crisis risk; intermediate: warning signs present.

Conversation_states.Description: Likelihood or ongoing signs of reverting to maladaptive behaviors/thoughts; guides relapse prevention planning and booster session need.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: low/no risk; 1.0: high risk/active relapse/warning signs; intermediate: at-risk/some setbacks.

Conversation_states.Description: Quality and stability of interpersonal relationships, social support access, assertiveness, and connectedness; relevant for skills training and planning.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: severe impairment/isolation/withdrawn; 1.0: highly functional, connected, assertive, strong support; intermediate: partial impairment.

Conversation_states.Description: Degree to which patient incorporates and recognizes positive evidence, strengths, and experiences into thoughts, mood, or session work.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: ignores/discounts positives; 1.0: actively seeks, values, integrates positives; intermediate: occasional recognition.

Conversation_states.Description: Degree and type of repetitive thinking, rumination, and focus on internal sensations/thoughts versus external tasks/environment; guides attention/mindfulness interventions.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: no rumination, externally focused; 1.0: constant rumination, internally/self-focused; intermediate: fluctuating attention.

Conversation_states.Description: Current session phase (beginning, middle, end/termination/booster); guides process focus such as alliance building, skill teaching, and relapse prevention.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: start of session; 1.0: end/termination; values in between map to intermediate phases.

Conversation_states.Description: Therapist’s confidence, emotional state, boundaries, and degree of interference from own thoughts; influences session focus and intervention quality.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: low self-efficacy, poor boundaries, high interference; 1.0: high self-efficacy, well-focused, energized; intermediate: variable competence.

Conversation_states.Description: Accuracy, collaborative nature, and relevance of current case conceptualization or diagnosis; determines intervention targeting and patient understanding.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: unclear, outdated, incorrect/no diagnosis; 1.0: crystal clear, collaborative, diagnosis confirmed; intermediate: partial fit.

Conversation_states.Description: Degree to which CBT is adapted to patient’s culture, developmental stage, and individual context; impacts engagement and effectiveness.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: no adaptation/insensitive; 1.0: fully responsive and tailored; intermediate: partial adaptation.

Conversation_states.Description: Quality, regularity, and consistency of sleep including disturbances and maladaptive patterns; guides intervention and tracks progress.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: severely disturbed; 1.0: restorative/healthy sleep; intermediate: mild disturbances.

Conversation_states.Description: Severity and impact of physical symptoms related to psychiatric status (fatigue, appetite, somatic symptoms); informs intervention focus.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: absent; 1.0: severe, persistent symptoms; intermediate: mild.

Conversation_states.Description: Intensity and frequency of addictive cravings, urges, and triggers; guides relapse prevention and coping skill planning.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: none/abstinent; 1.0: constant, overwhelming cravings; intermediate: occasional.

Conversation_states.Description: Degree of preoccupation and distress about physical appearance, checking, or avoidance behaviors; relevant for BDD/eating disorder protocols.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: none/neutral/accepting; 1.0: distorted, severe preoccupation; intermediate: moderate concern.

Conversation_states.Description: Level of worry, checking, reassurance-seeking, and catastrophic interpretation of health or bodily sensations.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: absent; 1.0: severe, persistent; intermediate: mild/moderate.

Conversation_states.Description: Presence and impact of additional psychiatric or substance use disorders alongside the main target; guides prioritization and intervention.
Conversation_states.Numerical values: 0.0: no comorbidities; 1.0: multiple, severe comorbidities; intermediate: minimal impact.

knowledge_graph.description: Individual undergoing CBT, representing all relevant cognitive, emotional, behavioral, and contextual info.
Clinical diagnosis and presenting problems, DSM criteria, symptoms, impairments, comorbidity.
Precipitating events, specific symptoms, and impairments affecting functioning.
Specific psychological or psychopathological symptoms (e.g., depression, anxiety, panic, compulsions, avoidance).
Disrupted areas of functioning (social, occupational, relational, self-care, problem-solving).
Multiple disorders or conditions (e.g., substance abuse, relationships, medical issues).
Past, present, or anticipated events recalled by the patient.
Memory biases, schemas, emotional/rational learning, procedural vs. declarative processes.
Beliefs, assumptions, predictions, core beliefs, and cognitive biases held by the patient.
Automatic thoughts and meanings assigned to events.
Immediate, often negative or distorted thoughts arising in response to situations.
Automatic thoughts most strongly linked to mood, typically rated for intensity.
Negative or exaggerated predictions, often triggering distress or panic.
Underlying core beliefs, assumptions, rules influencing thoughts and behaviors.
Assumptions, rules, attitudes influencing automatic thoughts.
‘If...then…’ rules or beliefs beneath automatic thoughts, contributing to persistent patterns.
Deep, enduring convictions about self, others, or world; drive thoughts, emotions, behaviors.
Dysfunctional core belief systems originating from developmental history.
Global, deep-seated beliefs influencing thoughts, emotions, and behaviors.
Mistaken or biased patterns in thinking (e.g., catastrophizing, all-or-nothing, personalization).
Common cognitive distortions like black-and-white thinking, catastrophizing.
Distorted thinking (e.g., overgeneralization, magnification, minimization) in thoughts or schemas.
Process of challenging negative/catastrophic thoughts with alternative evidence-based thinking.
Underlying rules or maladaptive beliefs (shoulds, intolerance for anxiety or uncertainty).
Unhelpful, distorted cognitive patterns or beliefs.
Patient’s emotional responses, intensity, and mood states during therapy (e.g., sadness, anxiety, anger).
Emotional states (depression, anxiety, anger, etc.), including frequency, strength, and duration.
Body sensations related to emotional or behavioral states.
Physical reactions associated with mood or distress (e.g., anxiety, arousal, sleep).
Physiological responses such as tension, rapid heartbeat, fatigue.
Observable actions, patterns (e.g., avoidance, activation, coping, rituals, withdrawal).
Current engagement, pleasure, mastery, scheduling, withdrawal.
Actions to evade distressing situations (e.g., escape, distraction, safety signals).
Behavioral avoidance or safety strategies (situational avoidance, reassurance seeking).
Actions or strategies to feel safer or temporarily relieve anxiety.
Behavior to prevent harm, often maintains anxiety or phobia.
Scheduling and engagement in pleasurable/mastery activities.
Activity scheduling to counter low mood, avoidance, and anhedonia.
Adaptive/maladaptive ways patient manages stress, distress, or problems.
Adaptive skills (problem-solving, relaxation, mindfulness, emotion regulation, assertiveness).
CBT and life skills (problem-solving, communication, assertiveness, relaxation, social skills).
Defining problems, generating solutions, evaluating and implementing outcomes.
CBT techniques (cognitive restructuring, activity scheduling, assertiveness, relaxation, mood tracking).
Specific CBT interventions (Socratic questioning, guided discovery, thought record, behavioral experiments, role play, imagery).
CBT interventions, behavioral activation, exposure, cognitive restructuring, skills training, medication education.
Session summaries, coping cards, beliefs, adaptive responses (written or audio).
Visual/formal mapping of links between thoughts, beliefs, emotions, and behaviors.
Current and ongoing issues prioritized for discussion/intervention.
Session agenda, collaboratively set, linking session topics to therapy goals.
Tasks assigned to practice skills and strategies between sessions.
Assigned practice tasks (behavioral activation, exposure, monitoring, skill training).
Monitoring of change, improvement, setbacks, relapse prevention, and practice.
Documentation and demonstration of symptom changes, improvement, impairments, homework compliance.
Logging and rating of mood, behaviors, thoughts, and goal attainment over time.
Diary/log for monitoring positive states and factors interrupting well-being.
Level and sources of drive for change and goal pursuit.
Patient’s motivation and barriers for maintaining ongoing records.
Defined, specific, observable CBT or personal development goals.
Specific, measurable, observable objectives for mood, behavior, or recovery.
Identification and breakdown of long-term recovery goals.
Goals focused on symptom reduction and improved functioning.
Written plan with goals, steps, obstacles, and strategies to address problems or implement new behaviors.
Structured plan for ongoing CBT practice.
Weekly record plotting number of panic attacks and average weekly anxiety.
Daily rating of anxiety, depression, and panic worry (0-10 scale).
Structured documentation of panic attacks, triggers, symptoms, emotional intensity.
Recording of panic, anxiety, symptoms, thoughts, triggers, and behaviors.
Distinction between emotional/subjective ratings and factual/objective symptom recording.
Cycles, triggers, and fluctuations in anxiety, panic, thoughts, and behaviors.
Episodes of acute panic experienced by the patient.
Mistaken or subjective beliefs about the harmfulness of panic symptoms.
Education on biological mechanisms and information about panic symptom harmlessness.
Pattern of anxiety, avoidance, anticipation, and reinforcement in 'unsafe' situations.
Graded list or ranking of feared or avoided situations for exposure practice.
Repeated exposure facing feared situations or symptoms.
Direct exposure to feared physical symptoms via exercises.
Slow, diaphragmatic breathing for anxiety regulation.
Skills in cognitive restructuring, evidence review, coping thought generation.
Participation of partner, family, or friends in supporting recovery and exposures.
Behaviors by helpers that may reinforce anxiety/avoidance or recovery behaviors.
Process of forgiving self or others, such as letter-writing and self-compassion work.
Recording or expressing things the patient is grateful for to boost mood/core beliefs.
Structured forms (Thought Record, Mood Ratings, Fear Ladder) used during therapy.
Relationships, strengths, and therapist collaboration aiding recovery.
Education to enhance understanding of CBT principles and techniques.
Integration of medication management with CBT (adherence, psychoeducation, monitoring).
Patient’s use, tapering, or withdrawal from medications.
Impact of physical illness, disability, sleep, acquired brain injury.
Personal responsibility for events, outcomes, and change.
Appraisal of self-worth, patterns of self-criticism, acceptance vs. self-rating.
Global or situation-specific self-evaluations, perfectionism, self-worth, self-criticism.
Social relationships, communication, trust, assertiveness, social anxiety.
Quality of interactions with others, intimacy, withdrawal, approval seeking.
Personal values, meaningful pursuits, alignment with priorities and chosen lifestyle.
Sociocultural, socioeconomic, developmental, medical, and contextual influences.
Patient's background, developmental stage, preferences affecting CBT approach.
Quality of trust, collaboration, rapport, teamwork, empathy, boundaries in therapy.
Collaborative planning, motivation, reflection, dynamics, alliance, goal setting.
Involvement in CBT (homework, sessions, collaboration, self-help, willingness for help).
Ongoing feedback between patient and therapist on progress, understanding, and alliance.
Problem definition, solution generation, implementation, evaluation.
Tracking of therapy change, setbacks, relapse prevention, and continued practice.
Ongoing self-monitoring and skill maintenance after initial CBT gains.
Strategies for managing setbacks and recurrence.
Strategies and plans for maintaining gains and handling setbacks post-therapy.
Education and planning to sustain progress and prevent symptom return.
Structure of therapy including goals, interventions, session frequency, and rationale.
Objective facts supporting or contradicting thoughts/beliefs; used in cognitive restructuring.
Adaptive thinking developed by weighing evidence against negative thoughts.
Structured tests of assumptions or beliefs to facilitate cognitive and behavioral change.
Setup, execution, and reflection on behavioral tests for beliefs/hypotheses.
